Fantastic place for cool photos. Wish there were a few more places to sit or to hangout on the green space.

OMG. It's just wonderful. Full disclosure--back in the 1980s, I worked at the Des Moines Art Center and loved the city. But this is really a new and hoppin' place. But back to the Sculpture Park. It's a grassy set of slopes with important and beautifully sited sculptures. It is
very close to downtown Des Moines. I liked seeing the new copper library and then the park. I had good Vietnamese food afterwards at A Dong
This sculpture park is free. It's a city block square. All the sculptures are tagged with the artist's name and the year completed. We enjoyed the walk-about.
The sculptures are really neat and detailed. Had fun taking pictures of it and really enjoyed the park too. Stop by here if you're around the area. Really cool sculptures!

Awesome place to walk around and check out some cool and interesting art, there was even a food truck parked on the corner just a neat place to go, especially if you are into Pokémon Go lots of pokestops and tons of drowzee

If you want to see a collection of uniques art, this is a must see in the Midwest. This is such a fine collection that it is used as a backdrop for one of the most exclusive art shows in the country. Close to dining, library, and other amenities as well.
There are so many beautiful sculptures to look at. All are so different yet all make quite a statement. Great to just wander through here and plenty of stops to sit and soak it all up.

The Pappajohn family had all of these sculptures in their yard and donated them to the City for the sculpture walk. It's definitely worth the walk thru the park - each sculpture is totally unique and one of a kind.
We had gone to the art museum earlier that afternoon and decided to stop by the outdoor sculpture park before leaving town, and we're very glad we did!

So glad our city is trying to build its culture and provide some art abd green spaces. However, the selection of art pieces is atrocious! You have black and white balls, a crazy mean looking rabbit, items that look like kidney beans, again in metal and not pretty. With as much

Lots of great areas to sit and relax while the kids ran around catching Pokemon. Lots of families enjoying the park and spending time together. The kids had lots of fun and we were able to relax under a shade tree.

My wife and I went there to check out the art. Our two kids (11 and 13) were there for Pokemon Go. My guess is that about 20% were there for art, 80% for Pokemon Go. Which was fine with us; it was good to see so many people at the attraction compared to the last time we were

Thanks to John & Mary Pappajohn Des Moines has an A rated sculpture garden. Relaxing. Excellent variety of grade A pieces. Surrounded by nice eating establishments. Come yourself and place to be Des Moines proud with out of town guests!

What makes this park special is that it is a beautifully laid out sculpture park that serves as a welcome to the downtown and is free of charge. The sculptures represented works by well known contemporary artists. There was no evidence of vandalism and there were many people

The park is nicely set up and it was good to stretch the legs a little and walk around to the different sculptures. There are not a lot, but it is free, and according to the sign there is an audio tour you can look up. If you miss it don't worry about it, but if you want a nice

It was fun! I brought my dogs with me and took pictures with the sculptures. They have a lot of sculptures and at night it is all lit up. Parking you have to pay with meter so heads up there. Also a lot of people there playing Pokemon go! I would definitely make it a point to

I'd never been to Des Moines before, so we decided to visit the sculpture park while in the area. On street parking is coin meters. Unfortunately, I didn't have any change with me. The 1st parking garage that I pulled into was also coin metered. I finally found a garage that
Nice place to walk and see a wide range of sculptures in a variety of materials. I saw a few of sculptors I had heard off.
Pokemon Go and sculpture fun. Great way to connect with your teenage kids. Stations are there to call and find out more about the sculptures.
Very nice. Enjoyed all the sculptures and the park area. Very pretty and kept nice. I think everyone should visit it once.
it is a great place to visit if you have never seen it. it add a very nice green space for downtown. Lately has been over ran by pokemon players

I'm not much into the avant-garde and modernist art thing. I'm told it is a great sculpture park. There a several pieces there I just don't get, but then again, I'm not an art person. The green space is very nice. In a nice area and well maintained. It's a nice place to walk

There are so many neat and different sculptures in a space that is big enough that it's not crowded, but yet small enough that you can see everything. Plenty of photo ops and very easy to get around, even for those that have difficulty walking.

People seem to love this place. I've lived in Des Moines for awhile now and never understood the hype. If you like really abstract art then I guess you'd like this place but the art kinda looks like a joke to me. The things they call some of the pieces is ridiculous. The piece

High quality sculptures set outdoors near the west end of downtown Des Moines. Many sculptures by recognized artists. My fave is the metal human form composed of letters of the alphabet. It speaks of our inextricable link with language & symbol. Powerful!
very relaxing just looking at the art sculptures and just going for a stroll by yourself or with friends

After seeing the sculpture parks of Loveland, CO we were a little disappointed in the size of the park. However, with that being said it was a pleasant hour spent walking around the park, watching people and admiring the art we understood. Each to his own. And it was free and

This park has a tremendous amount of art that will just make you stop and appreciate it. It's called pappajohns not because of the pizza, that's what I thought for like years, it turns out all the art was either at the house of a business man whose last name was Pappajohn. The

We were driving cross country and needed a great place to take a little break. This was the perfect location. The sculptures were lovely, the grass is perfectly maintained and there were some fun food trucks on the perimeter to provide lunch. It was just great!!

We liked it. Simple. Nice grassy spot downtown to walk on barefoot. Right-size for younger fams and grandparents. Great addition to the Arts Festival. Think I could have made some of this stuff...ha...
Whilst I'm no art critic I enjoyed looking at the free sculpture park named after the Pappajohns. Well laid out and you can spend as long as you want there. It's free.

Very nice to visit, especially since it is free! The sculptures were very interesting and thought provoking. You can spend as little or as much time as you want to. We found the park on trip advisors and also an app I have called "Roadside Attractions". I felt alittle silly

While the Papajohn Sculpture Park is a great attraction to visit, be warned some of the sculptures are a bit questionable. There are several along Grand Avenue resembling giant spiders & larvae. Strange yet worth the visit assuming you go with low expectations. As compared to
My husband and I enjoyed a stroll through the park, while the rest.of humanity stared at their phones. Quite comical & enjoyed the peacefulness!
The Sculptures were interesting, and the park well taken care of, but it was crowded with Pokeman players... Not sure I understand...
This was a nice surprise in the city. Great place to wander leisurely in the outdoors. Unique art, great story behind it.

The sculptures are awesome! My boyfriend is not very big into art, but he loved it! The alphabet head is very cool. You can walk right into it, it's huge! The mirror/color exhibit is awesome! You can see about 20 reflections of yourself. It made for some really nice pictures.
This was a very interesting sculpture garden with some very distinctive sculptures. My favorite was the head made out of the alphabet which was big enough to walk inside of it.
Visited the park in the daylight and then returned at night to see that several sculptures were more interesting during the evening.

Neat little park. The kids enjoyed stretching their legs and running around. There was plenty of metered parking along both sides. It was $0.45 for 1 hour. There were also some restaurants right around the park you could grab food at. I don't think it's something we'd do again,
Spent an easy hour meandering the park. Someone has more creative ability than I. Take a camera, and stretch your imagination.
I absolutely loved seeing this place! All the sculptures are a sight to see. So beautiful! My kids enjoyed running around while I was able to enjoy the art.

One square block of large sculptures with a small plaque identifying the artist, year and name of the piece. Some of the pieces are interactive and kids seemed to be enjoying their time there. Plenty of green space to sit and enjoy the view. Wide walking path around and through
This was an interesting and pleasant sculpture park in downtown Des Moines. Interactive interesting sculptures and it is free to visit. There are concerts in the park in the summer.

Very interesting place to visit. Wished I would have known or at least ventured downtown more often when I lived in West Des Moines a few years back so I could see what has changed through the years. My favorite was the horses made from driftwood .

We are traveling from Texas on a Midwest road trip and found this park on a list of things to do in Iowa. Our visit was on a Tuesday evening around 7:30PM which was very pleasant weather wise to be out strolling in the park. The sculptures were interesting and trying to figure
a very interesting park, with many wonderful sculptures. very good for those who like to be outdoors in contact with nature.
Some of the finest pieces of sculptures in the world. A really fun park to wonder through the sculptures with great places to eat and drink around the park

This free park in downtown Des Moines is a pleasant way to spend 10 minutes or 2 hours. There are more than 20 sculptures with winding sidewalks wandering between them. All sculptures are modern art, so if you're looking for a Rodin better head to the Des Moines Art Center. But
The term world-class gets thrown about a lot and often, without merit. The sculptures in this park are truly world-class and by world renowned artists.

Iowa has been great! The sculpture park and the Art Festival was a nice way to spend Saturday. Plenty of people and detailed works of art to enjoy. Children rolling down the hills brought back memories of my childhood home.

This is an easy park to walk around and catch great sculptures/photos on your trip. We went with young children and teens and they LOVED it!!! Beautiful and quirky exhibits and the same time-but all very fun.
A lovely park in downtown Des Moines with interesting sculptures providing an opportunity to leisurely walk around and take in the scene.

I have been to this outdoor exhibit a few times and have seen something different each time. My favorite is the Nomade. Make sure you look at Moonrise from the correct angle. In downtown Des Moines, there are great restaurants nearby. It makes a nice afternoon.
This is a wonderful addition to the city. We enjoyed a casual stroll to and through the garden. Not too abstract so great for a part time art viewer.
This is a downtown art park. Sculptures are interesting and impressive. Plan to spend at least a couple of hours if you really want to enjoy the park. Worth the trip if you are already in the area.
great addition to the Des Moines landscape with open green space for all to enjoy. Onsite metered parking and sometimes host truck food events.

The City of Des Moines has outdone itself in making this homage to the sculptural arts possible. The sculptures are varied. The setting is sublime. This park creates a gateway to the city that took years to establish. It was well worth the wait.

This is a great place to people watch or relax. There are several sculptures to look at (it seems more are added monthly). Right now, it's not crowded with art so there is lots of green space plus places to sit.
Came into town for a conference had a free hour and went to check out the sculpture park. Loved it! Lots of cool pieces ...not huge...but perfect if you have 30-60 min to kill!

This is a world-class sculpture park and has become a favorite destination for both out-of-town visitors and locals wanting an unusual backdrop for photographs. It's open year-round and looks different in every season. Plan to spend about an hour reading about and appreciating
A small, yet wonderful park full of fascinating sculptures in downtown Des Moines. Definitely worth your time.

I visited on an amazing weather day. This park as beautiful sculptures in it, and they are spread out across a huge lawn so you have enough space to admire them without bumping into anyone. There were even people lying under trees enjoying the weather. I was happy to see that

This is a nice place to check out while in Des Moines. There is metered parking all around the park so make sure you have some quarters! The sculptures are well done and spread out over a large area. There is no cost to view the sculptures.
There are some neat sculptures, but it's in a small area, and it's not a place I would visit more then once

If you are downtown you can't miss seeing this park. Modern rabbits sit around ( like one at Washington University in St Louis) and horse like sculptures amid other larger sculptures look strangely at home together in this urban park. It is interesting to walk among the art
This park was located in downtown and was near some other things we went to see. It is totally worth a half hour of time to walk around it and to see the cool sculptures.

You can stroll through this park leisurely and read the provided guided tour booklet to truly understand the works of art and the artists' visions. Or you can let your kids run through the park and pose by their favorite sculpture. There's no right or wrong way to enjoy this

It was a beautiful day to be outside and the walk through the slightly winding path of the Pappajohn Sculpture Park was a perfect setting. There is no admission and no gates that interfere with the beautiful pathways. The park hosts a collection of widely varying sculptures.

Creative and interesting sculpture park just on the outskirts of the downtown core of Des Moines. It's a relatively small park that's easy to walk around, and the sculptures are curious, even enigmatic.
Very unique stop! Even if you don't like abstract or other forms of art, there is something for everyone here!

My husband and I went to college in Des Moines in the 90's. We have made a few trips back and this sculpture park is unique and a lovely addition to the downtown. It makes for some cool photo ops! Highly recommend a stop. It's a quick jaunt, or take a picnic and lounge!

My husband & I visited here on his business trip. Beautiful garden and easy walk and informational. The sculptures and pagoda was beautiful. Right on the river and clean. Only wish that they had a translation plaque next to the stones. All and all a very nice free garden to walk
I didn't like most of the sculptures, but that is dependent on personal taste. It was nice to walk around with my husband and have something to do though.
The sculpture park is a great place to just sit and even greater when the festivals and food trucks arrive. The sculptures are unique and interesting. I think everyone should see them.

This sculpture park is worth your time to stop. I have been here many times, and never get tired of the works of art. It is especially beautiful at night. I was happy to see an exit for the park off of 235, and the food trucks are there. It would be a great place for lunch!

You have to visit the sculpture park during the day and also at night. My favorite has to be the Kaleidoscope, great place to get special pictures. You have to bring your camera. You can get so many cool pictures. I love to also go at dusk and just sit and watch the people
On a nice day, this would be a fun family activity. Great opportunity to get a little art education on vacation.

The artwork displayed here is predominantly attractive and interesting. It's also very wide open. Overall a should-see if you're in the city. There is an area that I didn't like as much, as it seemed to portray "spooky" sculptures. I'm not a personal fan of this, nor do I think

Kids will enjoy these odd sculptures and have fun running around on the grass. It is a great place to have a picnic and The Central Library is also close by (but check library's opening times.) Free fun for all.

After visiting the beautiful classical capitol building, we experienced a total change of perspective by walking through this sculpture park. Very well maintained and presented. We picked up a pamphlet at one end of park and enjoyed our time appreciating the art and artist

Located in the heart of downtown Des Moines, you'll be amazed at these unique sculptures and beautiful park. While you are visiting you can take some really great photos of and with the sculptures and even rent a bicycle to explore more parts of this safe and vibrant city!

Very varied sculpture in a park like setting. another plus is that there are several nice restaurants around the park to have lunch. One can spend more or less time examining the various works depending on your level of interest. A good place for taking photographs.

Visiting this place was a unique and interesting experience in itself. The park is very well maintained and sculptures are unique. Park is open all the time and you can also have a guided tour (call based) if that interests you. It's a small park, easily accessible and right
The sculptures were unique and the park setting made it fun for the entire family. Easy access to the area from downtown.
Open year round. Love it that it is downtown and next to small lunch shops/food trucks. Great to grab a bite and walk around during lunch time.

This is all in about a 2 block space. Nothing exciting except the sculptures are super cool. Make sure you have change for the meters as there doesn't appear to be freee public parking. The sculptures are all unique and it's just a nice little walk in the middle of downtown.

It's a small collection of world class sculptures. I visited on a chilly February day with my young kids who enjoyed walking most of the park before they got bored and I had to get them back in the car before I was done.

Delightful in every way. Great for children an wedding photo opportunities. Everyone should view this treasure. Don't neglect the audio tour available on your cell. Parking was abundant (and free) on this sunny April Saturday.

John and Mary Pappajohn Sculpture Park is in downtown between Grand Ave. and Locust from 13th to 15th streets. There are 27 modern sculptures. Most people like to take picture with Nomade, which was formed by painted stainless steel letters. If you are tired of walking in
Well worth the walk around the garden to view the sculptures. Interesting sculptures and descriptions.
Beautiful walk on a nice day. I'm happy Des Moines has kept some green space downtown and made it interesting with the art. The alphabet head is becoming a DSM icon.
Be prepared to be amazed if you haven't spent time at this site. It is stunning! Not what you may expect of a Midwestern community, but you probably wouldn't find anything like it anywhere.
Pick up a brochure (or not) and enjoy a wonderful 1/2 day walking around the park. The sculpture is fun and highly photogenic. I will return!

I expected a bit more from this sculpture park. I visited in a cloudy day which didn't help. If you have lots of time in Des Moines then it's worth a peek. However, if your time is limited, I would skip it.

While visiting downtown, we like to either drive by or walk through the sculpture park. Its full of curious statues and abstract sculptures that one should see. It is good for a stroll, if you've got a little extra time on your hands.

Everyone should stop in and see the wonderful art work in this park, its a great asset to downtown Des Moines and its close to so many resteraunts. Check it out at sunset if you have time, my favorite time to go.

Definitely come visit the sculpture garden during the fabulous Des Moines Art Festival in June! Unique scuptures donated by John and Mary Pappajohn give the entrance into the city a classy feel. Then stop by Centro for dinner. Across the street, be sure and visit

Des Moines isn't a huge spot for tourists, everyone knows that. If if was, this would be like a mini version of New York central park. Many locals walk around during lunch and on nice weekends many families come out to enjoy the day. Even for people who aren't into art it can be
Excellent afternoon for a walk around the sculpture garden. The brochure is very well done & the sculptures are all wonderful. This is an excellent space in the downtown area.

This is a fun place to walk regardless of month or time of day. The sculpture garden is a great addition to the city and it's a fun place to take out-of-town guests while eating or strolling through downtown.
This sculpture garden is right in the heart of the city. Interesting pieces, and plenty of place to sit, relax, and reflect, as well.
WAlk among these sculptures and ponder the ideas of the sculptors. Enjoy the views of nearby buildings.
One sunny day I had some time so I walked through the park and took many pictures. I enjoyed a bench to sit on and took in the whole experience. A very beautiful experience.
Who doesn't enjoy looking at art especially huge and unusual art pieces . Get a little exercise as you walk around the park. It's a win win!

The multi-block area has many large and wonderful sculptures. Many of which kids can climb. It's a good place for families or individuals to kill time or to become educated concerning art. It's outside vast, clean and there are a lot of eateries within a stone's throw.

Some of the pieces are genuinely good, like the letter man. But some pieces are just plain garbage. Anything can be art anymore, but that doesn't mean that it is or should be. Good place to stroll on a summer day though.

The Sculpture Park is a great place to walk around with friends or on a date. I live in Des Moines and I come here very often because I always find something new that I like about it. It is not super big (it takes up about a block of space), but the art is great and engaging.

Literally and figuratively the art in Western Gateway Park is accessible. You can touch and interact with the art and the art is discernible. We enjoyed the sculptures and the setting. we were there in june so also enjoyed the Des Moines Art Fair.

It's a very nice sculpture park. It makes for an enjoyable evening stroll. It is a well maintained park and a draw to that area. It looked to me like the area is being re-vitalized. A number of people were there enjoying the park.
What a beautiful, unique entrance into the city of Des Moines. Gorgeous winter, spring, summer or fall and provides a magnificent backdrop for food and music events throughout the year.

I always drive by there and never stop. Today, I stopped and slowly walk by things that have been built. It's beautiful art work. I understand puts art work at his home. That's neat. I think everyone in Des Moines or comes to our city, should go visit the art work there.

Interesting sculptures scattered around this urban art park. A little chilly in winter-best visited in the summer when the grass is green. The Des Moines Art Festival is held in this area later in the summer-a wonderful outing!

I have been all over North America and have not really seen a park as unique as this one. Set along to blocks it has hosted art festivals in the summer time. All the art is very large and some you can actually stand inside. It worth a trip to this location if your in the Des

What a gift the Pappajohns gave to the Des Moines community! A world class sculpture garden in the heart of downtown Des Moines, Iowa. Walk, tour or wander - all are acceptable. There is a free audio tour available. The garden is a round the clock photo opportunity for amateur

This sculpture park is one of my favorite places to take visitors to Des Moines. I love that our Art Center members and donors like the Pappajohns make art accessible to everyone, not just the economic elite, in our capital city.

We went in Oct. on a beautiful fall day. Does Moines has put so much time, effort and money into their downtown. It is an attraction for everyone. The sculpture garden was serene, colorful and very unique. The photo ops are amazing. No touching the sculptures but...
Had my daughters prom pictures here. The kaleidoscope is an amazing backdrop for any pictures. The alphabet is also a unique picture backdrop.

This is a great introduction to sculpture for all ages, set in a 4.4-acre green space, with the Des Moines skyline as a backdrop. Food trucks park close by in the summer, so you can sit on a bench, eat a delicious but inexpensive lunch, and watch people and art. Afterward, walk

Well worth your trip if you are even just a casual art fan. World class sculptures are located in a very nice green space. This neighborhood has been undergoing a major transformation and the results are incredible. Private/public partnership is making this an art destination

This is a testament to the ongoing connection between Des Moines French legacy and it's modern metropolis. Weathering the brutal Midwest winters, stands a public art installation of contemporary sculptures of varying media. Worth the walk through year round.
Really enjoyed walking the kids through the park, always good to see the new additions. Des Moines downtown is filled with wonderful art work

This park is well connected to the downtown area and is a good place to visit while here in Des Moines. It is only a small stroll from any of the downtown hotels and well worth the effort. When I was here they had food trucks surrounding the park, which was an added advantage.

The Pappajohn Sculpture Park is an unexpected treat with its pieces by well-regarded artists in a nicely landscaped green. It is loosely linked to other plazas and a riverside park in downtown Des Moines in a contemporary City Beautiful effort. Together they bring needed open
Very interesting statues, great place to bring a book, or picnic lunch and just sit and unwind. Easy walking distance from the downtown area and hotels.

This sculpture park is unique to Des Moines, Iowa. It is iconic to everyone who lives in the area and for good reason. Right in the heart of downtown this sculpture park is perfect for an afternoon stroll, a picnic or even a place to step out of the office and breathe. It is

Garden is easy to access on drive by or walking . On street parking is available. Sculptures themselves are not overly interesting, and none are titled so very hard to understand artists objectives. However, concept is nice addition to downtown, even if I found the art itself
Found this amazing sculpture garden in the heart of Des Moines. Excellent examples of modern sculpture. Very worth a trip downtown. A great way to spend a sunny day in Des Moines.

I had read mixed reviews of this park before arriving in Des Moines -- so I wasn't sure it was worth seeing -- but I asked a local who raved about it and I'm really glad we took the time. What an interesting mix of fascinating pieces and a beautiful setting (plus it's all free
Really good park with beautiful sculptures. There are cell phone tours available and also booklets at the corner of the place. Made really good pictures over there!
If you're in the city and have some extra time, I would use it to walk the grounds. The time of year and condition of the property probably had something to do with our experience.

After a fantastic wedding anniversary celebration at the Americana Restaurant and Lounge it was the best place to walk - quiet, serene, peaceful and an experience every visitor to the wonderful city of Des Moines should have.

Located in downtown Des Moines Iowa. I went on a Tues and there was plenty of parking nearby (metered took quarters, .50 gave me about and hour) Many sculptures with name titles and artist. There are brochures in a box that tell about each piece or there is a number to call for

I come from Minneapolis. We have an amazing sculpture park. I state this to let you know what I always compare these kinds of parks to. I was not impressed with the acutal sculptures. However, all art to me is interesting to explore and it was a nice day - so a nice walk around
it is a park downtown , near alot of things to do and beautiful sculptures . Walk around take picture , phone tour for each piece of art.

I hope that tax revenue was not spent to commission this "art". It is better than a big open field I suppose. I am sure some would say that I am just not "open minded" enough to understand random scrap metal in various shapes.
What a wonderful, beautiful experience. The many attractions are unique, and the landscaping is wonderful. It's a nice place to walk and let your imagination run wild.
Well laid out, large art pieces. Very clean, within walking distance of downtown hotels. Large grassy areas perfect for families with small children to play.
A great walk with anyone to see these artists imagination, we typically see this at the arts festival.
Nice amenity in middle of downtown but it did challenge my appreciation of art. Maybe it's the more abstract I got get. My problem, maybe not yours. Glad we walked through and considered them all.

This is about 2 square grass-covered blocks containing about 20 large and very creative sculptures. It's worth the trip---doesn't take very long to see them all---a half-hour or so. But you'll need to get the interpretive brochure somewhere else such as the Des Moines Art
Des Moines does so many things right, and this is a prime example. Lovely grounds and some fine sculpture. Get a brochure to fully appreciate the art.

I live opposite the sculpture park (and have done for the past year). The park is a great place for a wander in the summer months, either during the week early morning (6 am) or in the evening. I'm a keen amateur photographer and love taking pictures at sunrise and sunset with
Loved t! I would go at night to see the sculptures when they are lit. Jaume Plensa's piece is certainly the highlight!
This is a beautiful Sculpture Park that probably gets overlooked. I have been there several times taking out of state company. It is especially beautiful at night.

Yes its great that this is free to the public but frankly there is not one sculpture I like (or that anyone else I know likes for that matter) and I can only think the "artists" had to give the pieces away they are so awful. Otherwise, there is grass to walk or sit on which is

This park is one block long and one narrow block wide. Beautiful park with metal and composite sculptures throughout the park. This is a terrific place to take the kids or to just walk around the park and looking at the sculptures. A few are pretty wild but most are
Great place for photos and a brisk walk! If this is your first or one of many trips to the park, you will always find a new treasure.

The Papa John family has spent a lot of money around central Iowa and this is a Des Moines Gem. Trying to pick a day when someone isn't taking senior, family, wedding or engagement pictures is nearly impossible. The artwork/statues are beutiful and some are just very odd. It is

This is a smaller sculpture park but is very nice. If you park over by the library, you can walk through all the sculpture work. Lots of fun photo opportunities available. Love the quality of the art within the park. For a smaller area this is worth a visit.
The sculpture park is cool, not much to it. Plan about 30-40 minutes. Some are definitely more interesting than others.

This is a great park in downtown Des Moines, with inexpensive metered parking surrounding it. The sculptures are varied, and a free brochure located in stands around the park gives you the background on the park and the sculptures. It is well worth a visit, and I want to go back

The art park is one of my favorite places in Des Moines to go relax, walk around and enjoy all the interesting art pieces. The location as well as the park were designed perfectly to give you the feeling that you need to return.

This green space is filled with post-modern, mostly non-figurative sculpture. While most of the art is not compelling, there is something serene about this space. Moreover, it's flanked by many of the best restaurants in downtown, and parking is not too hard to get. Consider a

We went to Pappajohn sculture park but it was very dissapointing,with only a couple of decent sculptures to view the rest was rubbish. The steel horses and the alphabet body are the main attraction the rest are a waste of time,it was free and ok to walk around but go out of your
Nice stop for a leisurely walk around the park. Neat sculptures right in the heart of downtown. You can get info on the pieces by calling a phone #.

A very unique park in the city. We visited the park on a weekday morning and parking was easy to find. Our family loved the leisurely walk around the park looking at the sculptures. There was a couple of food trucks and restaurants nearby if you were looking for a bite to

This is a great example of public art and the cooperation of philanthropy, corporate sponsors and the city. You'll really enjoy your visit here in the morning or late-evening. Grab a meal from a nearby restaurant, eat at one of the many benches or bring a blanket and relax on
Just a great place to stroll through with your girl and a cup of coffee. Stop and admire the sculptures, have a coffee, relax and let the world pass by!
Such a beautiful spot downtown - we leisurely walked along the park and enjoyed it very much. Recommended!
Lots of photo ops. Beautiful sculptures with lots of green space. Our son had his wedding pictures taken here.

The most beautiful downtown experience. I went out to dinner and after took a stroll through the park. It was such a breath of fresh air to see something so beautiful in a downtown area. I could have lingered around for hours taking it all in. This is a must do while I'm Des
Very unique place to see. Good area to walk around. It's a must do especially if you are not from the area. It's free.
Beautiful and very clean. My shoes (Toms) got a little bit wet though, coz it had rained the night before. Nice sculptures.
Very creative pieces. Well worth the effort to tour the outside exhibit and best of all it is free to everyone.

The artwork is funky and fun. A lovely thing to do before or after a lunch or dinner downtown. It is wheelchair accessible, sidewalks all around. Street parking us usually ample but you will have to feed the parking meters. If touring on foot in Des Moines, park on one of
Always a fun area to stroll through. Plenty of photo opportunities. Interesting to see the new pieces that are added.
If you have kids, this is a fun little park to walk around on a nice day. Lots of stopping points. Parking might be a problem on the weekdays.

We had hoped to park the car and wander but did the slow crawl by as a concert had closed the park and there were no parks handy. What we saw was great and well worth the trip into Des Moines, maybe next time we will get to see them close up.

What a treat. Outdoor sculpture right in the center of town. Lots to look at. Have been collecting Claes Oldenburg visits for nearly 40 years and was delighted to see his trowel planted in the grass. Entire sculpture garden is 3 or 4 blocks. Don't miss it.

text.wiki:
Des Moines ( (listen)) is the capital and the most populous city in the U.S. state of Iowa. It is also the county seat of Polk County. A small part of the city extends into Warren County. It was incorporated on September 22, 1851, as Fort Des Moines, which was shortened to "Des Moines" in 1857. It is located on, and named after, the Des Moines River, which likely was adapted from the early French name, Rivière des Moines, meaning "River of the Monks". The city's population was 214,237 as of the 2019 population estimate. The six-county metropolitan area is ranked 83rd in terms of population in the United States with 699,292 residents according to the 2019 estimate by the United States Census Bureau, and is the largest metropolitan area fully located within the state. A portion of the larger Omaha, Nebraska, metropolitan area extends into three counties of southwest Iowa.Des Moines is a major center of the US insurance industry and has a sizable financial services and publishing business base. The city was credited as the "number one spot for U.S. insurance companies" in a Business Wire article and named the third-largest "insurance capital" of the world. The city is the headquarters for the Principal Financial Group, the Meredith Corporation, Ruan Transportation, TMC Transportation, EMC Insurance Companies, and Wellmark Blue Cross Blue Shield. Other major corporations such as Wells Fargo, Voya Financial, Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company, ACE Limited, Marsh, Monsanto, and DuPont Pioneer have large operations in or near the metropolitan area. In recent years, Microsoft, Hewlett Packard, and Facebook have built data-processing and logistical facilities in the Des Moines area. Forbes ranked Des Moines as the "Best Place for Business" in both 2010 and 2013. In 2014, NBC ranked Des Moines as the "Wealthiest City in America" according to its criteria.Des Moines is an important city in U.S. presidential politics; as the state's capital, it is the site of the first caucuses of the presidential primary cycle. Many presidential candidates set up campaign headquarters in Des Moines. A 2007 article in The New York Times said, "If you have any desire to witness presidential candidates in the most close-up and intimate of settings, there is arguably no better place to go than Des Moines."


== Etymology ==
Des Moines takes its name from Fort Des Moines (1843–46), which was named for the Des Moines River. This was adopted from the name given by French colonists. "Des Moines" (pronounced [de.mwan] (listen), formerly French pronunciation: ​[de.mwɛn]) translates literally to either "from the monks" or "of the monks".
The historian Virgil Vogel claimed that the name was derived from Moingona, an Algonquian clan name, which means "Loon".Some historians and researchers lacking linguistic or Algonquianist training concluded that Moingona meant "people by the portage" or something similar, a reference to the Des Moines Rapids. This was where the earliest known encounters between the Moingona and European explorers took place.One popular interpretation of "Des Moines" ignores Vogel's research, and concludes that it refers to a group of French Trappist monks, who in the 17th century lived in huts built on top of what is now known as the ancient Monks Mound at Cahokia, the major center of Mississippian culture, which developed in what is present-day Illinois, east of the Mississippi River and the city of St. Louis. This was some 200 miles (320 km) from the Des Moines River.


== Prehistory ==


=== Prehistoric inhabitants of early Des Moines ===

Based on archeological evidence, the junction of the Des Moines and Raccoon Rivers has attracted humans for at least 7,000 years. Several prehistoric occupation areas have been identified by archeologists in downtown Des Moines. Discovered in December 2010, the "Palace" is an expansive, 7,000-year-old site found during excavations prior to construction of the new wastewater treatment plant in southeastern Des Moines. It contains well-preserved house deposits and numerous graves. More than 6,000 artifacts were found at this site. State of Iowa archaeologist John Doershuk was assisted by University of Iowa archaeologists at this dig.At least three Late Prehistoric villages, dating from about AD 1300 to 1700, stood in or near what developed later as downtown Des Moines. In addition, 15 to 18 prehistoric American Indian mounds were observed in this area by early settlers. All have been destroyed during development of the city.


== History ==


=== Origin of Fort Des Moines ===
Des Moines traces its origins to May 1843, when Captain James Allen supervised the construction of a fort on the site where the Des Moines and Raccoon Rivers merge. Allen wanted to use the name Fort Raccoon; however, the U.S. War Department preferred Fort Des Moines. The fort was built to control the Sauk and Meskwaki Indians, whom the government had moved to the area from their traditional lands in eastern Iowa. The fort was abandoned in 1846 after the Sauk and Meskwaki were removed from the state and shifted to the Indian Territory.The Sauk and Meskwaki did not fare well in Des Moines. The illegal whiskey trade, combined with the destruction of traditional lifeways, led to severe problems for their society. One newspaper reported:

"It is a fact that the location of Fort Des Moines among the Sac and Fox Indians (under its present commander) for the last two years, had corrupted them more and lowered them deeper in the scale of vice and degradation, than all their intercourse with the whites for the ten years previous".After official removal, the Meskwaki continued to return to Des Moines until around 1857.Archaeological excavations have shown that many fort-related features survived under what is now Martin Luther King, Jr. Parkway and First Street. Soldiers stationed at Fort Des Moines opened the first coal mines in the area, mining coal from the riverbank for the fort's blacksmith.


=== Early, non-Native American, settlement ===

Settlers occupied the abandoned fort and nearby areas. On May 25, 1846, the state legislature designated Fort Des Moines as the seat of Polk County. Arozina Perkins, a school teacher who spent the winter of 1850–1851 in the town of Fort Des Moines, was not favorably impressed:

This is one of the strangest looking "cities" I ever saw... This town is at the juncture of the Des Moines and Raccoon Rivers. It is mostly a level prairie with a few swells or hills around it. We have a court house of "brick" and one church, a plain, framed building belonging to the Methodists. There are two taverns here, one of which has a most important little bell that rings together some fifty boarders. I cannot tell you how many dwellings there are, for I have not counted them; some are of logs, some of brick, some framed, and some are the remains of the old dragoon houses... The people support two papers and there are several dry goods shops. I have been into but four of them... Society is as varied as the buildings are. There are people from nearly every state, and Dutch, Swedes, etc.
In May 1851, much of the town was destroyed during the Flood of 1851. "The Des Moines and Raccoon Rivers rose to an unprecedented height, inundating the entire country east of the Des Moines River. Crops were utterly destroyed, houses and fences swept away." The city started to rebuild from scratch.


=== Era of growth ===
On September 22, 1851, Des Moines was incorporated as a city; the charter was approved by voters on October 18. In 1857, the name "Fort Des Moines" was shortened to "Des Moines", and it was designated as the second state capital, previously at Iowa City. Growth was slow during the Civil War period, but the city exploded in size and importance after a railroad link was completed in 1866.In 1864, the Des Moines Coal Company was organized to begin the first systematic mining in the region. Its first mine, north of town on the river's west side, was exhausted by 1873. The Black Diamond mine, near the south end of the West Seventh Street Bridge, sank a 150-foot (46 m) mine shaft to reach a 5-foot-thick (1.5 m) coal bed. By 1876, this mine employed 150 men and shipped 20 carloads of coal per day. By 1885, numerous mine shafts were within the city limits, and mining began to spread into the surrounding countryside. By 1893, 23 mines were in the region. By 1908, Des Moines' coal resources were largely exhausted. In 1912, Des Moines still had eight locals of the United Mine Workers union, representing 1,410 miners. This was about 1.7% of the city's population in 1910.
By 1880, Des Moines had a population of 22,408, making it Iowa's largest city. It displaced the three Mississippi River ports: Burlington, Dubuque, and Davenport, that had alternated holding the position since the territorial period. Des Moines has remained Iowa's most populous city. In 1910, the Census Bureau reported Des Moines' population as 97.3% white and 2.7% black, reflecting its early settlement pattern primarily by ethnic Europeans.


=== "City Beautiful" project, decline and rebirth ===

At the turn of the 20th century, Des Moines undertook a "City Beautiful" project in which large Beaux Arts public buildings and fountains were constructed along the Des Moines River. The former Des Moines Public Library building (now the home of the World Food Prize); the United States central Post Office, built by the federal government (now the Polk County Administrative Building, with a newer addition); and the City Hall are surviving examples of the 1900–1910 buildings. They form the Civic Center Historic District.
The ornate riverfront balustrades that line the Des Moines and Raccoon Rivers were built by the federal Civilian Conservation Corps in the mid-1930s, during the Great Depression under Democratic President Franklin D. Roosevelt, as a project to provide local employment and improve infrastructure. The ornamental fountains that stood along the riverbank were buried in the 1950s, when the city began a postindustrial decline which lasted until the late 1980s. The city has since rebounded, transforming from a blue-collar industrial city to a white-collar professional city.

In 1907, the city adopted a city commission government known as the Des Moines Plan, comprising an elected mayor and four commissioners, all elected at-large, who were responsible for public works, public property, public safety, and finance. Considered progressive at the time, it diluted the votes of ethnic and national minorities, who generally could not command the majority to elect a candidate of their choice.
That form of government was scrapped in 1950 in favor of a council-manager government, with the council members elected at-large. In 1967, the city changed its government to elect four of the seven city council members from single-member districts or wards, rather than at-large. This enabled broader representation of voters. As with many major urban areas, the city core began losing population to the suburbs in the 1960s (the peak population of 208,982 was recorded in 1960), as highway construction led to new residential construction outside the city. The population was 198,682 in 2000 and grew slightly to 200,538 in 2009. The growth of the outlying suburbs has continued, and the overall metropolitan-area population is over 600,000 today.
During the Great Flood of 1993, heavy rains throughout June and early July caused the Des Moines and Raccoon Rivers to rise above flood-stage levels. The Des Moines Water Works was submerged by flood waters during the early morning hours of July 11, 1993, leaving an estimated 250,000 people without running water for 12 days and without drinking water for 20 days. Des Moines suffered major flooding again in June 2008 with a major levee breach. The Des Moines river is controlled upstream by Saylorville Reservoir. In both 1993 and 2008, the flooding river overtopped the reservoir spillway.
Today, Des Moines is a member of ICLEI Local Governments for Sustainability USA. Through ICLEI, Des Moines has implemented "The Tomorrow Plan", a regional plan focused on developing central Iowa in a sustainable fashion, centrally-planned growth, and resource consumption to manage the local population.


== Cityscape ==

The skyline of Des Moines changed in the 1970s and the 1980s, when several new skyscrapers were built. Additional skyscrapers were built in the 1990s, including Iowa's tallest. Before then, the 19-story Equitable Building, from 1924, was the tallest building in the city and the tallest building in Iowa. The 25-story Financial Center was completed in 1973 and the 36-story Ruan Center was completed in 1974. They were later joined by the 33-story Des Moines Marriott Hotel (1981), the 25-story HUB Tower and 25-story Plaza Building (1985). Iowa's tallest building, Principal Financial Group's 45-story tower at 801 Grand was built in 1991, and the 19-story EMC Insurance Building was erected in 1997.
During this time period, the Civic Center of Greater Des Moines (1979) was developed; it hosts Broadway shows and special events. Also constructed were the Greater Des Moines Botanical Garden (1979), a large city botanical garden/greenhouse on the east side of the river; the Polk County Convention Complex (1985), and the State of Iowa Historical Museum (1987). The Des Moines skywalk also began to take shape during the 1980s. The skywalk system is 4 miles (6.4 km) long and connects many downtown buildings.In the early 21st century, the city has had more major construction in the downtown area. The new Science Center of Iowa and Blank IMAX Dome Theater and the Iowa Events Center opened in 2005. The new central branch of the Des Moines Public Library, designed by renowned architect David Chipperfield of London, opened on April 8, 2006.
The World Food Prize Foundation, which is based in Des Moines, completed adaptation and restoration of the former Des Moines Public Library building in October 2011. The former library now serves as the home and headquarters of the Norman Borlaug/World Food Prize Hall of Laureates.
In 2002, the Principal Financial Group and the city announced plans for the Principal Riverwalk, which will feature trails, pedestrian bridges across the river, a fountain and skating plaza, and a "civic garden" in front of the City Hall. Multiple existing downtown buildings are being converted from office to loft apartments and condominiums. This trend is highlighted by the success of the East Village district of shops, studios, and housing between the Capitol district and the Des Moines River.


== Geography ==

According to the United States Census Bureau, the city has an area of 90.65 square miles (234.78 km2), of which 88.93 square miles (230.33 km2) is land and 1.73 square miles (4.48 km2) is covered by water. It is 850 feet above sea level at the confluence of the Raccoon and Des Moines Rivers.
In November 2005, Des Moines voters approved a measure that allowed the city to annex parcels of land in the northeast, southeast, and southern corners of Des Moines without agreement by local residents, particularly areas bordering the Iowa Highway 5/U.S. 65 bypass. The annexations became official on June 26, 2009, as 5,174 acres (9.27 square miles) and around 868 new residents were added to the city of Des Moines. An additional 759 acres (1.18 square miles) were voluntarily annexed to the city over that same period.


=== Metropolitan area ===
The Des Moines-West Des Moines Metropolitan Statistical Area consists of five central Iowa counties: Polk, Dallas, Warren, Madison and Guthrie. The area had a 2000 census population of 481,394 and an estimated 2014 population of 768,927. The Des Moines-Newton-Pella Combined Statistical Area consists of those five counties plus Jasper and Marion Counties; the 2000 census population of this area was 550,659, and the estimated 2009 population was 631,805. Des Moines' suburban communities include Altoona, Ankeny, Bondurant, Carlisle, Clive, Grimes, Johnston, Norwalk, Pleasant Hill, Urbandale, Waukee, West Des Moines, and Windsor Heights.


=== Climate ===
At the center of North America and far removed from large bodies of water, the Des Moines area has a hot summer type humid continental climate (Köppen Dfa), with warm to hot, humid summers and cold, snowy winters. Summer temperatures can often climb into the 90 °F (32 °C) range, occasionally reaching 100 °F (38 °C). Humidity can be high in spring and summer, with frequent afternoon thunderstorms. Fall brings pleasant temperatures and colorful fall foliage. Winters vary from moderately cold to bitterly cold, with low temperatures venturing below 0 °F (−18 °C) quite often. Snowfall averages 35.3 inches (90 cm) per season, and annual precipitation averages 36.0 inches (914 mm), with a peak in the warmer months. Winters are slightly colder than Chicago, but still warmer than Minneapolis, with summer temperatures being very similar between the Upper Midwest metropolitan areas.


== Demographics ==


=== 2010 census ===
As of the census of 2010, there were 203,433 people, 81,369 households, and 47,491 families residing in the city. Population density was 2,515.6 inhabitants per square mile (971.3/km2). There were 88,729 housing units at an average density of 1,097.2 per square mile (423.6/km2). The racial makeup of the city for Unincorporated areas not merged with the city proper was 66.2% White, 15.5% African Americans, 0.5% Native American, 4.0% Asian, and 2.6% from Two or more races. People of Hispanic or Latino origin, of any race, made up 12.1% of the population. The city's racial make up during the 2010 census was 76.4% White, 10.2% African American, 0.5% Native American, 4.4% Asian (1.2% Vietnamese, 0.9% Laotian, 0.4% Burmese, 0.3% Asian Indian, 0.3% Thai, 0.2% Chinese, 0.2% Cambodian, 0.2% Filipino, 0.1% Hmong, 0.1% Korean, 0.1% Nepalese), 0.1% Pacific Islander, 5.0% from other races, and 3.4% from two or more races. People of Hispanic or Latino origin, of any race, formed 12.0% of the population (9.4% Mexican, 0.7% Salvadoran, 0.3% Guatemalan, 0.3% Puerto Rican, 0.1% Honduran, 0.1% Ecuadorian, 0.1% Cuban, 0.1% Spaniard, 0.1% Spanish). Non-Hispanic Whites were 70.5% of the population in 2010.There were 81,369 households, of which 31.6% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 38.9% were married couples living together, 14.2% had a female householder with no husband present, 5.3% had a male householder with no wife present, and 41.6% were non-families. 32.5% of all households were made up of individuals, and 9.4% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.43 and the average family size was 3.11.
The median age in the city was 33.5 years. 24.8% of residents were under the age of 18; 10.9% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 29.4% were from 25 to 44; 23.9% were from 45 to 64; and 11% were 65 years of age or older. The gender makeup of the city was 48.9% male and 51.1% female.


=== 2000 census ===
As of the 2000 census, there were 198,682 people, 80,504 households, and 48,704 families in the city. The population density was 2,621.3 people per square mile (1,012.0/km2). There were 85,067 housing units at an average density of 1,122.3 per square mile (433.3/km2). The racial makeup of the city was 82.3% white, 8.07% Black, 0.35% American Indian, 3.50% Asian, 0.05% Pacific Islander, 3.52% from other races, and 2.23% from two or more races. 6.61% of the population were Hispanic or Latino of any race. 20.9% were of German, 10.3% Irish, 9.1% "American" and 8.0% English ancestry, according to Census 2000.
There were 80,504 households, out of which 29.5% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 43.7% were married couples living together, 12.6% had a female householder with no husband present, and 39.5% were non-families. 31.9% of all households were made up of individuals, and 10.2% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.39 and the average family size was 3.04.
Age spread: 24.8% under the age of 18, 10.6% from 18 to 24, 31.8% from 25 to 44, 20.4% from 45 to 64, and 12.4% who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 34 years. For every 100 females, there were 93.8 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 90.5 males.
The median income for a household in the city was $38,408, and the median income for a family was $46,590. Males had a median income of $31,712 versus $25,832 for females. The per capita income for the city was $19,467. About 7.9% of families and 11.4% of the population were below the poverty line, including 14.9% of those under age 18 and 7.6% of those ages 65 or over.


== Economy ==
Many insurance companies are headquartered in Des Moines, including the Principal Financial Group, EMC Insurance Group, Fidelity & Guaranty Life, Allied Insurance, GuideOne Insurance, Wellmark Blue Cross Blue Shield of Iowa, and American Republic Insurance Company. Des Moines has been referred to as the "Hartford of the West" because of this. The Principal is one of two Fortune 500 companies with headquarters in Iowa, ranking 273rd on the magazine's list in 2009.As a center of financial and insurance services, other major corporations headquartered outside of Iowa have a presence in the Des Moines Metro area, including Wells Fargo, Voya Financial, and Electronic Data Systems (EDS). The Meredith Corporation, a leading publishing and marketing company, is also based in Des Moines. Meredith publishes Better Homes and Gardens, one of the most widely circulated publications in the United States. Des Moines was also the headquarters of Golf Digest magazine.
Other major employers in Des Moines include UnityPoint Health, Mercy Medical Center, MidAmerican Energy Company, CDS Global, UPS, Firestone Agricultural Tire Company, EDS, Drake University, Titan Tire, The Des Moines Register, Anderson Erickson, Dee Zee and EMCO.In 2010, Forbes magazine ranked the Des Moines metropolitan area first on its list of "Best Places For Business And Careers", based on factors such as the cost of doing business, cost of living, educational attainment, and crime rate.In 2017, Kemin Industries opened a state-of-the-art worldwide headquarters building in Des Moines.


== Culture ==


=== Arts and theatre ===

The City of Des Moines is a cultural center for Iowa and home to several art and history museums and performing arts groups. The Des Moines Performing Arts routinely hosts touring Broadway shows and other live professional theater. Its president and CEO, Jeff Chelsvig, is a member of the League of American Theatres and Producers, Inc. The Temple for Performing Arts and Des Moines Playhouse are other venues for live theatre, comedy, and performance arts.
The Des Moines Metro Opera has been a cultural resource in Des Moines since 1973. The Opera offers educational and outreach programs and is one of the largest performing arts organizations in the state. Ballet Des Moines was established in 2002. Performing three productions each year, the Ballet also provides opportunities for education and outreach.
The Des Moines Symphony performs frequently at different venues. In addition to performing seven pairs of classical concerts each season, the Symphony also entertains with New Year's Eve Pops and its annual Yankee Doodle Pops concerts.
The Metro Arts Alliance produces Jazz in July every year, that offers free jazz shows daily at various venues throughout the city during the entire month of July.

Wells Fargo Arena is the Des Moines area's primary venue for sporting events and concerts since its opening in 2005. Named for title sponsor Wells Fargo Financial Services, Wells Fargo Arena holds 16,980 and books large, national touring acts for arena concert performances, while several smaller venues host local, regional, and national bands. It is the home of the Iowa Wolves of the NBA G League, the Iowa Wild of the American Hockey League, and the Iowa Barnstormers of the Indoor Football League.
The Simon Estes Riverfront Amphitheater is an outdoor concert venue on the east bank of the Des Moines River which hosts music events such as the Alive Concert Series.
The Des Moines Art Center, with a wing designed by architect I. M. Pei, presents art exhibitions and educational programs as well as studio art classes. The Center houses a collection of artwork from the 19th century to the present. An extension of the art center is downtown in an urban museum space, featuring three or four exhibitions each year.

The Pappajohn Sculpture Park was established in 2009. It showcases a collection of 24 sculptures donated by Des Moines philanthropists John and Mary Pappajohn. Nearby is the Temple for Performing Arts, a cultural center for the city. Next to the Temple is the 117,000-square-foot (10,900 m2) Central Library, designed by renowned English architect David Chipperfield.
Salisbury House and Gardens is a 42-room historic house museum on 10 acres (4 ha) of woodlands in the South of Grand neighborhood of Des Moines. It is named after—and loosely inspired by—King's House in Salisbury, England. Built in the 1920s by cosmetics magnate Carl Weeks and his wife, Edith, the Salisbury House contains authentic 16th-century English oak and rafters dating to Shakespeare's days, numerous other architectural features re-purposed from other historic English homes, and an internationally significant collection of original fine art, tapestries, decorative art, furniture, musical instruments, and rare books and documents. The Salisbury House is listed on the National Register of Historic Places, and has been featured on A&E's America's Castles and PBS's Antiques Roadshow. Prominent artists in the Salisbury House collection include Joseph Stella, Lillian Genth, Anthony van Dyck and Lawrence Alma-Tadema.
Built in 1877 by prominent pioneer businessman Hoyt Sherman, Hoyt Sherman Place mansion was Des Moines' first public art gallery and houses a distinctive collection of 19th and 20th century artwork. Its restored 1,250-seat theater features an intricate rococo plaster ceiling and excellent acoustics and is used for a variety of cultural performances and entertainment.


=== Attractions ===

Arising in the east and facing westward toward downtown, the Iowa State Capitol building with its 275-foot (84 m), 23-karat gold leafed dome towering above the city is a favorite of sightseers. Four smaller domes flank the main dome. The Capitol houses the governor's offices, legislature, and the old Supreme Court Chambers. The ornate interior also features a grand staircase, mural "Westward", five-story law library, scale model of the USS Iowa, and collection of first lady dolls. Guided tours are available.
The Capitol grounds include a World War II memorial with sculpture and Wall of Memories, the 1894 Soldiers and Sailors Monument of the Civil War and memorials honoring those who served in the Spanish–American, Korean, and Vietnam Wars.
The West Capitol Terrace provides the entrance from the west to the state's grandest building, the State Capitol Building. The 10-acre (4 ha) "people's park" at the foot of the Capitol complex includes a promenade and landscaped gardens, in addition to providing public space for rallies and special events. A granite map of Iowa depicting all 99 counties rests at the base of the terrace and has become an attraction for in-state visitors, many of whom walk over the map to find their home county.

Iowa's history lives on in the State of Iowa Historical Museum. This modern granite and glass structure at the foot of the State Capitol Building houses permanent and temporary exhibits exploring the people, places, events, and issues of Iowa's past. The showcase includes native wildlife, American Indian and pioneer artifacts, and political and military items. The museum features a genealogy and Iowa history library, museum gift shop, and cafe.
Terrace Hill, a National Historic Landmark and Iowa Governor's Residence, is among the best examples of American Victorian Second Empire architecture. This opulent 1869 home was built by Iowa's first millionaire, Benjamin F. Allen, and restored to the late 19th century period. It overlooks downtown Des Moines and is situated on 8 acres (3.2 ha) with a re-created Victorian formal garden. Tours are conducted Tuesdays through Saturdays from March through December.
The 110,000-square-foot (10,000 m2) Science Center of Iowa and Blank IMAX Dome Theater offers seven interactive learning areas, live programs, and hands-on activities encouraging learning and fun for all ages. Among its three theaters include the 216-seat Blank IMAX Dome Theater, 175-seat John Deere Adventure Theater featuring live performances, and a 50-foot (15 m) domed Star Theater.

The Greater Des Moines Botanical Garden, an indoor conservatory of over 15,000 exotic plants, is one of the largest collections of tropical, subtropical, and desert-growing plants in the Midwest. The Center blooms with thousands of flowers year-round. Nearby are the Robert D. Ray Asian Gardens and Pavilion, named in honor of the former governor whose influence helped relocate thousands of Vietnamese refugees to Iowa homes in the 1970s and 1980s. Developed by the city's Asian community, the Gardens include a three-story Chinese pavilion, bonsai landscaping, and granite sculptures to highlight the importance of diversity and recognize Asian American contributions in Iowa.
Blank Park Zoo is a landscaped 22-acre (8.9 ha) zoological park on the south side. Among the exhibits include a tropical rain forest, Australian Outback, and Africa. The Zoo offers education classes, tours, and rental facilities.
The Iowa Primate Learning Sanctuary was established as a scientific research facility with a 230-acre (93 ha) campus housing bonobos and orangutans for the noninvasive interdisciplinary study of their cognitive and communicative capabilities.

The East Village, on the east side of the Des Moines River, begins at the river and extends about five blocks east to the State Capitol Building, offering an eclectic blend of historic buildings, hip eateries, boutiques, art galleries, and a wide variety of other retail establishments mixed with residences.
Adventureland Park is an amusement park in neighboring Altoona, just northeast of Des Moines. The park boasts more than 100 rides, shows, and attractions, including four roller coasters. A hotel and campground is just outside the park. Also in Altoona is Prairie Meadows Racetrack and Casino, an entertainment venue for gambling and horse racing. Open 24 hours a day, year-round, the racetrack and casino features live racing, plus over 1,750 slot machines, table games, and concert and show entertainment.
Living History Farms in suburban Urbandale tells the story of Midwestern agriculture and rural life in an 500-acre (2.0 km2) open-air museum with interpreters dressed in period costume who recreate the daily routines of early Iowans. Open daily from May through October, the Living History Farms include a 1700 Ioway Indian village, 1850 pioneer farm, 1875 frontier town, 1900 horse-powered farm, and a modern crop center.
Wallace House was the home of the first Henry Wallace, a national leader in agriculture and conservation and the first editor of Wallaces' Farmer farm journal. This restored 1883 Italianate Victorian houses exhibits, artifacts, and information covering four generations of Henry Wallaces and other family members.
Historic Jordan House in West Des Moines is a stately Victorian home built in 1850 and added to in 1870 by the first white settler in West Des Moines, James C. Jordan. Completely refurbished, this mansion was part of the Underground Railroad and today houses 16 period rooms, a railroad museum, West Des Moines community history, and a museum dedicated to the Underground Railroad in Iowa. In 1893 Jordan's daughter Eda was sliding down the banister when she fell off and broke her neck. She died two days later, and her ghost is reputed to haunt the house.The Chicago Tribune wrote that Iowa's capital city has "walker-friendly downtown streets and enough outdoor sculpture, sleek buildings, storefronts and cafes to delight the most jaded stroller".


=== Festivals and events ===

Des Moines plays host to a growing number of nationally acclaimed cultural events, including the annual Des Moines Arts Festival in June, Metro Arts Jazz in July, Iowa State Fair in August, and the World Food & Music Festival in September. On Saturdays from May through October, the Downtown Farmers' Market draws visitors from across the state and is ranked the second best market in the country. Local parades include Saint Patrick's Day Parade, Drake Relays Parade, Capitol City Pride Parade, Iowa State Fair Parade, Labor Day Parade, and Beaverdale Fall Festival Parade.
Other annual festivals and events include: Des Moines Beer Week, 80/35 Music Festival, 515 Alive Music Festival, ArtFest Midwest, Blue Ribbon Bacon Fest, CelebrAsian Heritage Festival, Des Moines Pride Festival, Des Moines Renaissance Faire, Festa Italiana, Festival of Trees and Lights, World Food & Music Festival, I'll Make Me a World Iowa, Latino Heritage Festival, Oktoberfest, Winefest, ImaginEve!, Iowa's Premier Beer, Wine & Food Show, and Wild Rose Film Festival.
